newsitem.title: FRANCE: Barry Callebaut eyes new investment in Ivory Coast.
newsitem.headline: Barry Callebaut eyes new investment in Ivory Coast.

text.p: Barry Callebaut AG said on Tuesday it planned to increase its cocoa processing capacity in the Ivory Coast.
"We are planning to invest in the Ivory Coast. We believe there is still room to increase capacity," board vice chairman Charles Gebhard told a news conference.
A group of company officials was travelling to the Ivory Coast to discuss the plan with local authorities, he added.
Barry Callebaut, formed by the merger of France's Cacao Barry and Swiss Callebaut AG, currently processes some 90,000 tonnes of cocoa beans in its three Ivorian plants.
It processes between 200,000 and 250,000 tonnes of cocoa beans worldwide and should reach a processing capacity of 300,000 tonnes this year, or 12 percent of world capacity.

Asked if the group planned to increase the capacity of existing plants or build a new factory in the Ivory Coast, Gebhard said, "We have not decided yet. It is possible that we will build a new site next to our existing site in Abidjan."
But he did not say what capacity the group had in mind.

Barry Callebaut has 19 production sites around the world. It will open a new production unit in Singapore in June with an initial capacity of 8,000 tonnes of chocolate. Capacity may later be raised to 20,000 tonnes.
